Today ‚Äì and every day ‚Äì #OH07 honors the history of the Cleveland Grays and recognizes the immeasurable sacrifice of its members in the fight to save freedom. We honor the bravery and legacy of thousands of Americans who died on that faraway shore so that our liberty would live.

By nightfall, while battling Nazi forces, The Cleveland Grays opened a roadway off Omaha Beach around the cliffs near Saint Laurant-Sur-Mer, thereby allowing Allied troops to move inland and help achieve success for the invasion.

Among the heroes who rushed ashore in France that day were members of the @OHNationalGuard 112th Combat Engineer Battalion, also known as the Cleveland Grays.¬† The battalion suffered 37 killed and 45 wounded on D-Day, including the commanding officer, Maj. William A. Richards. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fx8QZrnWAAUzD0-.jpg

The CHIPS and Science Act includes my COAST Research and Innovation Act, which will help coastal communities adapt to the climate crisis by expanding scientific research and monitoring of ocean and coastal acidification.

8/ The 2022 gun bill isn‚Äôt comparable to 1934 or 1993. 

But it was undoubtedly a signal - maybe the first real one in decades - that government will not condone sky high violence rates. 

And it‚Äôs not implausible that part of the 2023 reduction is people reacting to this signal.

7/ I think a version of the Hawthorne Effect applies to gun violence. When the government does nothing in the face of rising violence rates, the silence implies endorsement. 

But when the government acts boldly, it signals a value and norm. And some people react to that signal.

6/ In short, the Hawthorne Effect is the idea that people change their behavior (mostly for the better) when being watched or observed.

When someone is paying attention and passing judgment on conduct,  humans conform to norms. When no one cares, they often act outside of norms.

5/ Those measures had a practical impact on the ability of dangerous people to get guns.

But there was something else that happened too.

So to explain this, let me tell you about the Hawthorne Effect.

4/ The two most significant gun safety efforts in the 1900s were the 1934/1938 Firearms Acts and the 1993/1994 Brady Bill and assault weapons ban.

It isn‚Äôt a coincidence that the two biggest drops in violence rates happened following passage of the two biggest gun safety bills.

3/ So what explains those sharp declines in violence, and what does it tell us about this moment?

Here‚Äôs a partial theory: what happened in the 1930s that was repeated in the 1990s, and also has a (minor) corollary to 2022?

Answer: the passage of major gun safety legislation.

2/ This new dip may be temporary. But maybe/hopefully it‚Äôs the start of a trend.

It would represent the third major sharp decrease in U.S. violence rates over the last 100 years. 

Look at this chart. The last two dips were in the 1930s and the 1990s. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fx8wsNuakAApoM3.jpg

Gun violence rates are falling. Quickly. And the author of this article speculates that the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act is partly responsible.

I want to expand on that argument in a couple tweets.
